snippet.textDisplay: I tried that coffee when I saw it some Korean channel. Not my favorite for tasting of course but the thickness is lovely and it looks/feels great. I put espresso first, then milk and this lovely foam at the very top. Definitely worth trying.

snippet.textDisplay:
Questions:
1-maybe de regular instant coffee makes more foam because of contains canephora coffee?
2-could you try the same think with maybe 4 shots of espresso ristreto?
3-could we try to make a syrup with water and sugar, like a caramel and than adding the coffee? could it work better?
4- what if we forget the sugar and just shake the coffee? It looks like a iced latte anyway and I make a shaked filter coffee that have nice foam....
5-what if we add flavorless gelly like agar agar, or the white part of egg...its used already in coctelary...

thanks for the video! very nice review!

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve made this with espresso! I pull a double shot just a bit short, take a spoonful of the first bit of espresso to come out, and mix that with about two and a half teaspoons of sugar (sorry, James, I’m not a very exact human most of the time). I whip that with my handheld electric milk frother until it’s light and creamy, then add the rest of my espresso to the mix and whip it up until it’s as fluffy and creamy as I can get it. It looks very similar to what you had in the video, however there is just a little bit of coffee at the very bottom of the cup that stays liquid no matter what. Less than a tablespoon, though. I’m definitely a fan!
snippet.textOriginal: I’ve made this with espresso! I pull a double shot just a bit short, take a spoonful of the first bit of espresso to come out, and mix that with about two and a half teaspoons of sugar (sorry, James, I’m not a very exact human most of the time). I whip that with my handheld electric milk frother until it’s light and creamy, then add the rest of my espresso to the mix and whip it up until it’s as fluffy and creamy as I can get it. It looks very similar to what you had in the video, however there is just a little bit of coffee at the very bottom of the cup that stays liquid no matter what. Less than a tablespoon, though. I’m definitely a fan!

snippet.textDisplay:
Several thoughts:

First, this reminds my of a shakerato - espresso and simple syrup, shaken with ice to make a foam, then strained. The foam is less stable than this.

If your wanted to use espresso, and didn't mind reduced strength, you could use a foaming agent like versawhip. You could reduce the sugar as well. This might be a good option for not overdoing things.

Finally, getting into the gadgetry: it would be quite interesting to attempt concentration via freeze or nanofiltration methods.
snippet.textOriginal:
Several thoughts:

First, this reminds my of a shakerato - espresso and simple syrup, shaken with ice to make a foam, then strained. The foam is less stable than this.

If your wanted to use espresso, and didn't mind reduced strength, you could use a foaming agent like versawhip. You could reduce the sugar as well. This might be a good option for not overdoing things.

Finally, getting into the gadgetry: it would be quite interesting to attempt concentration via freeze or nanofiltration methods.

snippet.textDisplay: Looks good.  This seems really similar to how I make Cuban coffee. You start off with sugar and then add to it the first bit of coffee brewed in a  Moka Pot and then stir vigorously to create the espuma.  It has a very similar texture to the dalgona coffee.
snippet.textOriginal: Looks good.  This seems really similar to how I make Cuban coffee. You start off with sugar and then add to it the first bit of coffee brewed in a  Moka Pot and then stir vigorously to create the espuma.  It has a very similar texture to the dalgona coffee.

snippet.textDisplay: I tried the original recipe because I only had old instant coffee lying around my gf used to drink. I thought: "How disgusting could it be? James is probably just a big wussy that got his godlike tasty bits on his tongue overwhelmeed". Well. after stirring for 3 minutes straight I had a nice thick foam. I couldn't resist to taste it. And I immediately spitted it out. And wanted to chop of my tongue. It's that disgusting. The foam itself is undrinkable. I removed 2/3s of the foamy mass and mixed it well with the milk and ice and.. it tasted like a regular instant iced coffee. Exactly like you said. Note to self: Listen to James. James is a good dude. James tries to save your tasty bits on your own tongue by sacrificing his. Thanks, James!

snippet.textDisplay: When making Hard Cider, people tend to freeze and thaw apple juice to create a concentrate for sweetening, because the sugary juice components thaw before the clear ice, without negatively affecting flavour like with boiling. Same principle as sucking on ice pops, leaving just clear ice without all the flavours. I wonder whether this would also work with coffee.
snippet.textOriginal: When making Hard Cider, people tend to freeze and thaw apple juice to create a concentrate for sweetening, because the sugary juice components thaw before the clear ice, without negatively affecting flavour like with boiling. Same principle as sucking on ice pops, leaving just clear ice without all the flavours. I wonder whether this would also work with coffee.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have tried to make it using Indonesian coffee ground "Kapal Api" with using flat dripper with 1:4 coffee:water ratio.
Add sugar for sweetening and thicken the liquid.
Using milk frother to mix it and froth it and voila it can make a good creamy foamy coffee.


IMO almost all coffee can be use to make it as long as the water is not too much
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: James, your explanation is right but I think there might be something else aiding the formation of the foam. I'm not 100% sure but I guess the instant coffe has got some surfactants. I believe they add some to make the powder more soluble and probably it helps during the drying also. Hence, It might be intresting to use one of this surfactants (soy lecitin, to give an example) to make a foam with a good espresso, don't you think?
snippet.textOriginal: James, your explanation is right but I think there might be something else aiding the formation of the foam. I'm not 100% sure but I guess the instant coffe has got some surfactants. I believe they add some to make the powder more soluble and probably it helps during the drying also. Hence, It might be intresting to use one of this surfactants (soy lecitin, to give an example) to make a foam with a good espresso, don't you think?

snippet.textDisplay:
You have to mix it before drinking 🤣 I've expected that you not gonna like it, it's instant coffee 🙊

Btw, regarding using espresso, or rather not really espresso but using real coffee beans, if you look around (even in YouTube) Cuban coffee has long been using this method using the little bit of the first early pour of coffee coming out from moka pot, to be whisked with....wait for it... sugar 🤣 but the Cuban coffee version generally is not poured into milk, just with the rest of the coffee from the moka pot.

This only got viral and be called "Dalgona" because now Korea and its style & trends are the 'in' thing to millennials around the world, so it got popular easily when they see Korean youtubers and entertainers showed it... I guess 😅 I'm not k-pop enthusiasts so I have known this method from watching cuban coffee youtube videos, at first I was bewildered why do people calling it Dalgona? 🤷🏾‍♀️
snippet.textOriginal:
You have to mix it before drinking 🤣 I've expected that you not gonna like it, it's instant coffee 🙊

This only got viral and be called "Dalgona" because now Korea and its style & trends are the 'in' thing to millennials around the world, so it got popular easily when they see Korean youtubers and entertainers showed it... I guess 😅 I'm not k-pop enthusiasts so I have known this method from watching cuban coffee youtube videos, at first I was bewildered why do people calling it Dalgona? 🤷🏾‍♀️

snippet.textDisplay: "...coz, Maths all the way" is a bit of a problem in this context, because you calculated weight ratios off the volumetric ratios, so you're effectively using a recipe based on volume albeit with an added step of conversion in between. Maybe I've missed something obvious?
snippet.textOriginal: "...coz, Maths all the way" is a bit of a problem in this context, because you calculated weight ratios off the volumetric ratios, so you're effectively using a recipe based on volume albeit with an added step of conversion in between. Maybe I've missed something obvious?

snippet.textDisplay:
Meanwhile in Greece we have been drinking this kind of coffee for the last 4-5 decades. It is basically an upside down dalgona, but diluted with water (instead of milk). Of course you can add a bit of milk if you are up to it. It is called frappe and it is great for summertime (or all around the year). Since the 2000's, though, people here have been obsessed with a different kind of coffee (much better in taste of course, because f the espresso used) freddo espresso and freddo cappuccino which are basically cold espresso beaten to make it foamy-frothy with a hand mixer, ice cubes, cold water and cold frothy milk in the case of the cappuccino.
I am pretty sure James would like it better than instant coffee.
snippet.textOriginal:
Meanwhile in Greece we have been drinking this kind of coffee for the last 4-5 decades. It is basically an upside down dalgona, but diluted with water (instead of milk). Of course you can add a bit of milk if you are up to it. It is called frappe and it is great for summertime (or all around the year). Since the 2000's, though, people here have been obsessed with a different kind of coffee (much better in taste of course, because f the espresso used) freddo espresso and freddo cappuccino which are basically cold espresso beaten to make it foamy-frothy with a hand mixer, ice cubes, cold water and cold frothy milk in the case of the cappuccino. 
I am pretty sure James would like it better than instant coffee.

snippet.textDisplay: this is one of the few times, I am going to say Greeks have been doing this for ages with frappe, mixing instant coffee with water (and sugar) and the froth is so thick it never dissolved in the rest of the coffee, the glass was stained with a sticky residue. I always hated instant coffee... but at some point I thought of using it as an icing for cakes but instant coffee always put me off... oh well 7 grams of coffee 20g sugar 20g water, why not come up with something with real coffee? perhaps with the use of gelatine and cold brew, I have seen videos of people using milk with gelatine creating low fat (whipped) cream :( I don't see the point of this froth lol. it left me so unimpressed...
snippet.textOriginal: this is one of the few times, I am going to say Greeks have been doing this for ages with frappe, mixing instant coffee with water (and sugar) and the froth is so thick it never dissolved in the rest of the coffee, the glass was stained with a sticky residue. I always hated instant coffee... but at some point I thought of using it as an icing for cakes but instant coffee always put me off... oh well 7 grams of coffee 20g sugar 20g water, why not come up with something with real coffee? perhaps with the use of gelatine and cold brew, I have seen videos of people using milk with gelatine creating low fat (whipped) cream :( I don't see the point of this froth lol. it left me so unimpressed...

snippet.textDisplay: So my espresso science isn’t 100% up to speed, I do however have a deeper question regarding your comments about it not being concentrated enough. My interpretation of extraction is in the 1:2 ratio region with a ballpark of 30-35g of liquid extracted proportional to weight of dry coffee, if that is the case why is a ristretto type extraction unsuitable? Extract around 1:1, adjusting grind such flavour balance is somewhat maintained, is there a significant change in solubles in the ristretto that means it won’t foam? I acknowledge that mineral content in water can only extract a limited amount of solubles in a given volume of water, but could we not select an appropriate roast and origin to produce such an extraction?
snippet.textOriginal: So my espresso science isn’t 100% up to speed, I do however have a deeper question regarding your comments about it not being concentrated enough. My interpretation of extraction is in the 1:2 ratio region with a ballpark of 30-35g of liquid extracted proportional to weight of dry coffee, if that is the case why is a ristretto type extraction unsuitable? Extract around 1:1, adjusting grind such flavour balance is somewhat maintained, is there a significant change in solubles in the ristretto that means it won’t foam? I acknowledge that mineral content in water can only extract a limited amount of solubles in a given volume of water, but could we not select an appropriate roast and origin to produce such an extraction?

snippet.textDisplay: Espresso dalgano ftw! Equal parts espresso and sugar, frothed until you’re happy, then pour over iced milk and serve. Gets a really cool cascade effect going too. Nowhere near as foamy as the instant used in the video, but nails it in the flavour department. 👌
snippet.textOriginal: Espresso dalgano ftw! Equal parts espresso and sugar, frothed until you’re happy, then pour over iced milk and serve. Gets a really cool cascade effect going too. Nowhere near as foamy as the instant used in the video, but nails it in the flavour department. 👌

snippet.textDisplay: First, this drink is nasty and should not be drunk. Second, get a kitchenaid stand mixer, makes life so much better when it comes to whisking. And third , if people really like coffee and foam they should use said stand mixer and make a coffee flavoured souffle. Make a creme patissiere base, infuse it with coffee and combine with the egg whites to make a heavenly dessert.
snippet.textOriginal: First, this drink is nasty and should not be drunk. Second, get a kitchenaid stand mixer, makes life so much better when it comes to whisking. And third , if people really like coffee and foam they should use said stand mixer and make a coffee flavoured souffle. snippet.textDisplay:
The way i see it this is just a white frappe with the coffee on the top that is not mixed with the milk...
You can make the same texture of the coffee with frappe mixer.. and also you are wrong that you can not achieve this with espresso - you can, you can make it the same way freddo espresso is making just whisking it for a little bit more time...
were i work we make it like this:
one spoon of brown sugar in a pitcher where we pull double shot of espresso, we pour the coffee in a thin with a couple of ice and whisk it on frappe mixer until the texture is right

snippet.textDisplay:
First of all I love you, second of all in Naples (and Campania in general) it was common in coffee shops to have something similar to this instead of sugar to add to your coffee: they would take espresso, mix it with loads of sugar and whip it and then you would add that to your own espresso to make it sweeter. They don't do it anymore, or at least it has mostly fallen out of trend, due to sanitary reasons: there would be a cup of that syrup on the counter and you would take it yourself, so not the most hygienic practice...
Anyway, I love u, stay safe, bye bye
snippet.textOriginal:

They don't do it anymore, or at least it has mostly fallen out of trend, due to sanitary reasons: there would be a cup of that syrup on the counter and you would take it yourself, so not the most hygienic practice...

snippet.textDisplay:
It is strong, but normally if I beat it longer to stiff peaks, I can get 4-5 portions out of the recipe & be closer to regular strength. You just need to make sure the foam sticks to the edge of the glass before it gets wet with the milk or it will be difficult to stir into the milk afterward.

You can also achieve the same result with a lower coffee:sugar ratio, though the end result will be quite pale.
snippet.textOriginal:
It is strong, but normally if I beat it longer to stiff peaks, I can get 4-5 portions out of the recipe & be closer to regular strength. You just need to make sure the foam sticks to the edge of the glass before it gets wet with the milk or it will be difficult to stir into the milk afterward.

You can also achieve the same result with a lower coffee:sugar ratio, though the end result will be quite pale.

snippet.textDisplay: James, while anglicizing is a thing, Dalgona isn’t something anglicized. That is pretty much exactly how it’s called in Korea. We had a honeycomb coffee craze before with literal honeycomb coffee. Yes well it kind of tastes like honeycomb and it’s mentioned (and hence dalgona) but more contributing factor of it gaining its nickname is that the top foam resembles dalgona. The color, the texture, the way it kind of expands, are uncanny. I appreciate you are being sensitive but you can relax with this one. If anything we Koreans took a Macaw thing and Koreanized it.
snippet.textOriginal: James, while anglicizing is a thing, Dalgona isn’t something anglicized. That is pretty much exactly how it’s called in Korea. We had a honeycomb coffee craze before with literal honeycomb coffee. Yes well it kind of tastes like honeycomb and it’s mentioned (and hence dalgona) but more contributing factor of it gaining its nickname is that the top foam resembles dalgona. The color, the texture, the way it kind of expands, are uncanny. I appreciate you are being sensitive but you can relax with this one. If anything we Koreans took a Macaw thing and Koreanized it.

snippet.textDisplay: I enjoy the low brow version. Hand mixer in hand, 3 minutes later you got coffee, faster than your French press. Enjoy the eye appeal of the foam but then spare yourself and stir it. I like half milk half milk alternative, maybe a splash of half and half if I feel and a few drops of stevia if the instant coffee I picked up is too bitter. It’s just fun. Snobby people like plating, yawn, kids like fluffy food. Make dalgona coffee, soufflé pancakes, and soufflé omelette at the same time. So much fun and pretty simple once you get the techniques down. Minimal ingredients.
snippet.textOriginal: I enjoy the low brow version. Hand mixer in hand, 3 minutes later you got coffee, faster than your French press. Some like it better when they stir it together & drink it but actually I heard that the alternative version is better. Honestly, they all kinda taste like sweet coffee milk—
In this version, you crush 달고나(dalgona) into small chunky pieces and use them as toppings—some like this better especially if they prefer crunchy texture :)
P.S: There are few different easier ways to make it

snippet.textDisplay: This Dalgona Coffee is just like a greek Frappé, they've been doing it since the 60s. Dimitris Vakondios from nescafe invented it and it spread as a summer day coffee! :D The only difference is that they do the foam first in the bottom of a Collins glass from instant coffee (a special nescafe one, but some other ones work too), sugar and splash of water, whisk it with a coffee stick frother, fill the glass with ice, then add just water to it so some of the coffee from the foam gets dissolved into the water making it instantly coffee colored, stir it a bit, and finally through the thick foam left on top they pour a bit of cream, which beautifully weaves down between and around the ice cubes partially staying suspended beneath the foam. It is really refreshing at summertime! :D
snippet.textOriginal: This Dalgona Coffee is just like a greek Frappé, they've been doing it since the 60s. Dimitris Vakondios from nescafe invented it and it spread as a summer day coffee! :D The only difference is that they do the foam first in the bottom of a Collins glass from instant coffee (a special nescafe one, but some other ones work too), sugar and splash of water, whisk it with a coffee stick frother, fill the glass with ice, then add just water to it so some of the coffee from the foam gets dissolved into the water making it instantly coffee colored, stir it a bit, and finally through the thick foam left on top they pour a bit of cream, which beautifully weaves down between and around the ice cubes partially staying suspended beneath the foam. It is really refreshing at summertime! :D

snippet.textDisplay: That coffee aroma that comes out of a freshly opened jar isn't the coffee, it's a coffee smell  that is put into the jar and disperses. That's why it never smells the same when you open the jar again.
snippet.textOriginal: That coffee aroma that comes out of a freshly opened jar isn't the coffee, it's a coffee smell  that is put into the jar and disperses. That's why it never smells the same when you open the jar again.

snippet.textDisplay:
After watching this, I tried with reduced portion. Using my baking spoon measurements, 1 teaspoon of each.
2g instant coffee
6g sugar
5g hot water
I concur with James, volumetric measurement is tough when different regions use different sized cups and spoons.

snippet.textDisplay: James a bit of note when converting from metric to mass, consider the density of the compound. As we can see mass of 1 tablespoon of coffee is not the same as 1 tablespoon of sugar, so the ratio will not be 1:1 if we use 10g of coffee with 10g of sugar. It will be 1:1 ratio of mass but not volumetric. For the calculation of mass should be 1 tablespoon of sugar mass/mass of sugar needed = 1 tablespoon of coffee mass/mass of coffee given. Correct me if I am wrong.
snippet.textOriginal: James a bit of note when converting from metric to mass, consider the density of the compound. As we can see mass of 1 tablespoon of coffee is not the same as 1 tablespoon of sugar, so the ratio will not be 1:1 if we use 10g of coffee with 10g of sugar. It will be 1:1 ratio of mass but not volumetric. For the calculation of mass should be 1 tablespoon of sugar mass/mass of sugar needed = 1 tablespoon of coffee mass/mass of coffee given. Correct me if I am wrong.

snippet.textDisplay: Perfect pronunciation of dalgona Mr. Hoffman. I thought you actually studied Korean language when you said it. Not just pronunciation, but that flat, relaxed  tone you carried with the word just screamed Korean spirit outright. Could it be that 달고나 coffee having its effects on you?
snippet.textOriginal: Perfect pronunciation of dalgona Mr. Hoffman. I thought you actually studied Korean language when you said it. Not just pronunciation, but that flat, relaxed  tone you carried with the word just screamed Korean spirit outright. Could it be that 달고나 coffee having its effects on you?

snippet.textDisplay:
Ermmmmmmmm... James, you are supposed to stir and mix the foam with the milk before u drink it, that’s the last step in making this internet frappe. The foam and milk is only for presentation, u still need to incorporate them thoroughly...



Can you guys like this so he sees it...?

snippet.textDisplay:
Feeling validated watching this video for (having tried) and not liking this Dalgona coffee 'thing'.


It really just tastes like extreme strong instant coffee with a boatload of sugar. I'll stick to regular lattes, thank you.

snippet.textDisplay: Used to drink this a lot in india, tastes awesome to my pallet. The effort to prep this tho (washing the extra dishes and the ~5 mins of mixing) stops me from making it. also I dont like to consume sugar with my coffee anymore.
snippet.textOriginal: Used to drink this a lot in india, tastes awesome to my pallet. The effort to prep this tho (washing the extra dishes and the ~5 mins of mixing) stops me from making it. also I dont like to consume sugar with my coffee anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: You didn’t mix the first one, and didn’t properly mix the second one. Also, if it’s too strong try it with slightly less coffee. I did half the coffee in the recipe and kept the same amounts of water and sugar and that was much better.
snippet.textOriginal: You didn’t mix the first one, and didn’t properly mix the second one. Also, if it’s too strong try it with slightly less coffee. I did half the coffee in the recipe and kept the same amounts of water and sugar and that was much better.
